, but global shares remain low relative to other
Total solar and wind capacities in 2019 were 609 GW and 623
. The combined share of solar and wind in the total global electricity
Since 2015, the cost of solar PVs has declined by over 60%. Offshore wind costs have fallen by 32%,
and onshore wind costs have fallen by 23% (Section 6.4). PV was around 99% of total solar c
2019; onshore wind was about 95% of total wind capacity. Concentrating solar power (CSP)
deployment has also continued to grow, but it remains far below PV. Prior to 2010, 50% of all wind
capacity was in Europe, but, since then, capacity growth
in Asia, led by China, has surpassed the growth
in Europe. As a consequence, Europe’s share in global solar capacity has declined from 74% in 2010
to 24% in 2019. Asia’s share in wind and solar capacity in 2019 was 41% and 56%, followed by Europe
Global solar and wind electricity installed capacities (GW) from 2015
combined share in total electricity generation Source: data from
Although the shares of wind and solar remains low in the global total electricity generation, recent
growth rates signal the potential for these technologies to support substantial mit
for a continuation of recent growth rates will depend on meeting key challenges such as rapidly
y sources beyond wind and solar have continued to grow
carbon energy sources such as nuclear, hydropower, bioenergy, geothermal, marine, and fossil or

Bioenergy accounted for 2.4% of electricity generation
Geothermal energy sources produced 92 TWh yr
) in 2015 (IEA, 2017; IEA 2021a). At present, there are 28 commercially
